Ciao!

First time poster in this group, but wanted to share some of my experiences from my first three days in this beautiful country - Rome in particular.

I am travelling with my Mum who is in her mid-60’s. These are just our experiences, we understand that everyone is and travels differently!

Crowds
- Visit the sites early to avoid the crowds. We have been leaving the hotel (in Trastevere) at 7am and walking to the sites. There have been very few people around at this time of morning, and it is quite serene walking the quiet streets at that time of day.
NOTE - obviously if you are going into the sites you are bound by it’s opening hours, so crowds will be unavoidable.
- From 9am onwards you can see a noticeable difference in the crowds building.

Heat
- It has been super hot and humid, however we have been getting up early and sight seeing before the heat really kicks in at around 10am.
- Take a hand held fan (we bought some from home but they sell them everywhere here and are very cheap) - these make all the difference.
- Always carry a bottle of water and wear a hat (water is also very easily accessible at stores).
- We have been relaxing in our hotel in the hottest afternoon hours and enjoying siestas ☺️.

Safety
- We have not felt unsafe at all. Definitely pay more attention to your belongings around the main tourist sites - cross body bags for your most important belongings are great.
- Goes without saying, but have your wits about you and be aware of your surroundings (as you should wherever you are travelling in the world 😊).
- We haven’t ridden any busses, however these look super packed when they drive by, so probably hold your bags very close on these.

After reading some of the comments in this group I was feeling a little nervous about coming here with my Mum, however we have absolutely loved every second of our stay so far! Rome is so, so charming and yes the heat has made us adjust our ways of sight seeing, but it has not stopped us from doing anything we had planned to do!!

Off to Positano today, and cannot wait 🥰

text: Hello everyone. I've never been to Italy. It's top on my bucket list! But just curious about how much spending money for, souvenirs, food, and some excursions I should have for a family of 5

comments.comment_text: Just remember not to eat and drink right in the square of famous centres; St Marks square Venice, etc

Example: we sat at a cafe near the Florence Duomo - 5 cappuccinos and 5 pastries = 70 euro. The next day, at a small spot in Siena away from big sites, we paid $10 euro for the same thing. 🙃

Photos of the experience are your best souvenirs, IMHO, and what we do is look for one special piece of artwork, but even that can be low cost, there are some really interesing smaller postcards that are frameable.
